audio.transcript:
SECTION 2

Hello, my name is Ian Mathews and I'm here to talk about the Starbikers Charity Toy Run and the benefits it brings to sick and underprivileged children.

For those of you who are not familiar with the Charity Toy Run, it is an annual event held two weeks before Christmas Day which involves a parade of motorbike riders who ride across the city, collecting toys which are later distributed to children's wards in hospitals and institutions focused on helping under-privileged children. The day is concluded with a fund-raising event dedicated to children's charities which is held in the town hall.

The event benefits the children in a number of ways. Each participant in the run is required to pay 1 pound entry fee which is collected to cover administration costs of the day and the remainder is donated to charity. Participants are also required to donate a toy, and further toys are collected from spectators who gather to watch the procession of bikes as it makes it way around the city (all toys collected are later distributed in time for Christmas as mentioned before). After the parade is finished, non-participants in the run are welcome to join the bikers at the town hall charity event, which involves an entry fee of £1.50 to non-riders. Even those who cannot actually attend at any point of the day can still make a donation via the internet or mail.

We ask that bikers and other people who decide to donate toys do not wrap their toys in wrapping paper. We do not specify what type of toy or what age group of child to donate a gift for as we try to provide gifts for many different types of children. If gifts are wrapped it makes is more difficult for our administrators to match an appropriate gift with each child.

There are now many Charity Toy Runs organized in various cities throughout the world -all with similar aims though slightly different formats. The first in the UK was organized by our association, the Starbikers Charity Association and was held on December 18th 1978. Over the years, the atmosphere and formula of the event have changed quite dramatically. The original concept was geared very much towards motorbike enthusiasts and followers of rock music; however, in order to attract a wider audience and consequently increase the level of donations and support received, quite early on, several changes were made to improve the appeal of the event to a wider audience.

These days, the music played at the charity event is more varied and quieter than it was in the early days, a variety of food and drink stalls and corporate displays are present and activities such as face painting and entertainers mean that there is something to appeal to even younger members of the family. Although there are several new attractions, we continue to include the 'best motorbike' competition which has been a fixture of the day from the very beginning. All awards and prizes are donated on stage by the Lord Mayor and at the end of the evening we make an announcement as to how much money and how many toys the day has resulted in.

Anyone with a motorbike is able to participate in the run and anyone at all is able to attend the post-run event. Bikers do not need to register in advance, they simply need to be at the correct meeting point by the given time of day (these details are confirmed one month prior to the event) bringing their registration fee and toy donation with them. All of the people involved in the organization and administration of the day are volunteers and none of the money collected goes towards paying for organiser's wages. We do sometimes need to pay for performers, though increasingly over the years more and more are providing their services free of charge.

In order to keep the event safe, we have the full support of the police and we station our own traffic marshalls along the roads the parade will travel along. The police control major road junctions on the day so that the parade can stay together and does not need to constantly stop at traffic lights. We also strongly remind riders that the event is not a race but a slow parade of a group of motorbikes. On average around 2,000 motorbikes are involved in each toy run every year, so as you can imagine it is very important that all participants act responsibly on the day – which they do. We are very pleased with and proud of the attitudes, behaviour and support shown by our participants each year.

We have never cancelled a Toy Run due to bad weather, but may make changes to the route taken if road conditions are deemed dangerous on the day of the event due to ice or fog, using alternative roads to those originally planned. We advise all participants to dress in warm, waterproof clothing as the weather in December can be quite uncomfortable for motorbike riding and all participants are required to ride in appropriately protective clothing. The police advise us on any necessary changes to the parade arrangements and we keep the general public informed of such changes via local radio stations in case they are planning to watch the bikes go by.

Starbikers Charity Association is also responsible for the organization of the 'Egg Run' which is held two weeks before Easter and collects and delivers Easter eggs for distribution to children.
